image.altText: A blurred photo of dead labradoodle puppies, adult dogs and a lamb in a chest freezer.

props.synopsis: Former workers at Tasmania's then-largest puppy farm have broken their silence, revealing details about what they saw happen and were asked to do while working at Tasmanian Labradoodles.

title.children: 'The biggest mistake of my life': Former workers at labradoodle puppy farm speak out

image.altText: Rear view of new Spirit of Tasmania V ferry in shipyard.

props.synopsis: Severe winds have caused one of the two new Spirit of Tasmania vessels to break loose from its outfitting quay at a shipyard in Finland, but the extent of damage is yet to be determined.

title.children: 'Hurricane-force' winds caused new Spirit ships to come loose and drift into an embankment in Finland

image.altText: A young man in a grey shift appears to conduct musicians while holding a baton

props.synopsis: Becoming a conductor is about more than being good at reading music. A group of Australians have just secured their qualifications in Tasmania and it's more than just 'hand movements and a baton'.

title.children: Not just hand movements and a baton: The role of orchestra conductors explained

image.altText: Artist impression of planned ship terminal.

props.synopsis: Two Tasmanian government-owned businesses were at loggerheads over the rollout of new Spirit of Tasmania vessels, causing long delays and blowouts. Now they might be merged into one entity.

title.children: Rockliff proposes merging businesses responsible for Spirit of Tasmania fiasco

image.altText: Charlie Woolley smiles near a beach.

props.synopsis: Charlie, like so many others, had so much life left to live but sadly that was not to be. The memory of him, symbolised by shoes and his story, will be just one of many taken to Canberra to "raise awareness of the horrific effects and unimproved life expectancy from brain tumours".

title.children: Remembering Charlie and all the others gone far too soon because of brain cancer

image.altText: Green post next to road with SUV driving past

props.synopsis: Removing wildlife carcasses from the road is a usual morning for Jason Cichocki but he says a new technology has more than halved the number of animals colliding with vehicles.

title.children: Wildlife rescuers say roadkill 'virtual fence' saving hundreds of kangaroos

image.altText: A whale in the water as a fishing vessel approaches

props.synopsis: Two humpback whales were found dead in krill fishing nets near Antarctica earlier this year, while a third whale had serious injuries, a report from a conservation conference in Hobart has revealed.

title.children: 'Distressing': Dead and injured humpback whales found in krill fishing nets near Antarctica

image.altText: Helen Bird smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Helen Bird's friends never believed she would take her own life, leaving behind her three children. Fourteen years later, a coroner rules her husband made her death look like a suicide.

title.children: Coroner finds husband 'was involved' in wife's death, 14 years after it was deemed a 'suicide'

image.altText: Illustration of different women sliced up to make one person.

props.synopsis: In the past six months alone there have been countless stories of schoolboys targeting both peers and teachers with varying degrees of tech-assisted gendered bullying, harassment, and abuse.

title.children: 'But what if she sent them to him first?': Devastating words from a teenager show how growing up has changed

image.altText: Albanese smiles as a crowd surrounding him cheers.

props.synopsis: Labor has promised to bake in fee-free TAFE at a rally setting the party up for the coming federal election, saying if the government is re-elected it will make 100,000 fee-free places permanently available each year,

title.children: Albanese promises to lock in 100,000 fee-free TAFE places every year, in pseudo campaign launch

image.altText: a painted depiction of John Batman meeting with Kulin leaders at Merri Creek

props.synopsis: While the legacy of John Batman's 1835 treaty with Kulin elders is contested, the story of the violent entrepreneur who tried to bargain with Melbourne's Aboriginal owners is a defining moment in Victoria's colonial history.

title.children: In 1835, Tasmanian grazier John Batman attempted to make a treaty with Melbourne's Aboriginal owners. Here's what happened

image.altText: Students in graduation robes

props.synopsis: A re-elected Albanese government would reduce student debts by 20 per cent as part of a broader suite of changes to the system.

title.children: Re-elected Labor government would slash students debts by 20 per cent

image.altText: Mortar board sitting on a pile of money

props.synopsis: The federal government has proposed new changes to student loan repayments for cost of living savings. Here's what that could mean for you.

title.children: The HECS threshold is being increased and debts are being lowered but repayment times will take longer for some under a new proposal

image.altText: Two women with signs smile at the camera, with a large crowd of people visible behind them

props.synopsis: A Women's March event in the US capital has brought thousands to the streets in support of Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris.

title.children: 'Grab him by the ballot': Thousands join Women's March in Washington DC with messages for Trump

image.altText: A group of Brisbane AFLW players gather on the field to celebrate after a goal.

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lions' AFLW win over St Kilda puts them in with a shot for the McClelland Trophy and $1 million for the top combined men's and women's AFL club of the season but Hawthorn can clinch the prize with victory over Richmond.

title.children: AFLW win for Lions but advantage Hawks as $1 million up for grabs with McClelland Trophy

image.altText: Democratic presidential nominee and U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris

props.synopsis: It was Kamala Harris's first time on the show, which has had other presidential candidates over its decades-long run.

title.children: Kamala Harris opens Saturday Night Live, urging US to 'keep calm-ala' before election

image.altText: Nathan McSweeney plays a pull shot

props.synopsis: Nathan McSweeney underlines his Test credentials with a fine audition against India A, hitting the winning runs in a seven-wicket victory, as the tourists are cleared of ball-tampering after it initially appeared umpires accused them of causing scratches on it.

title.children: India A cleared of ball-tampering, no further action

image.altText: Aerial close up of aqua water, small whale calf on the left next to a larger whale, both with white patches on heads

props.synopsis: Scientists say southern right whale numbers have recovered in the Great Australian Bight Marine Park, and are now calling for further protection as they move into new areas.

title.children: Southern right whales are in abundance off Australia's south coast, but new threats have emerged

image.altText: A graphic of a red up arrow next to a percentage sign, overlaid on a street view of a row of houses.

props.synopsis: Even though inflation is within the RBA's ideal range, economists are banking on high interest rates hanging around for a little bit longer.

title.children: Here's when the big four banks reckon interest rates will go down

image.altText: Man wearing baseball cap holds a fish

props.synopsis: The Gallatin County Sheriff's office has now confirmed Daren Abbey, 41, has been arrested and charged in connection with the death of Dustin Kjersem, 35.

title.children: Man charged with murder at US campsite initially reported as bear attack

image.altText: A dingo glances towards the camera in the late afternoon light.

props.synopsis: They have roamed for thousands of years, their presence woven into the country's culture and ecosystems. But the increasing presence of dingoes in areas where farmers are grazing livestock is creating a complex and emotive challenge.

title.children: An iconic symbol of the outback is undergoing an identity crisis

image.altText: A man wearing a turban waves his hand

props.synopsis: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's speech comes as rockets fired from Lebanon injure 11 people in central Israel, according to Israeli emergency services.

title.children: Iran's supreme leader threatens Israel and the US with 'crushing response'

image.altText: Collage of Australian politicians on Red.

props.synopsis: Of Red's 150 million active users, almost 700,000 are based in Australia. That presents both opportunities and risks for Australian politicians.

title.children: China's super app 'Little Red Book' was branded as a lifestyle platform. It's now a PR battleground for some Australian politicians

image.altText: Pal Bidong, known in music circles as Peezy.

props.synopsis: The 20-year-old victim of a fatal shooting in Melbourne's inner north has been remembered as having a "beautiful heart" and always putting others first, as police continue to investigate the incident.

title.children: 'Loved by many': North Melbourne shooting victim identified as up-and-coming rapper

image.altText: Rehana Parvin in professional portrait

props.synopsis: The body of Australian-Bangladeshi citizen Rehana Parvin was discovered in September, buried in a small village in Bangladesh, two months after she went missing.

title.children: 'Five kids lost their mother': Family of Queensland woman allegedly murdered in Bangladesh speak out

image.altText: A Mogami class frigate at a naming and launching ceremony in Nagasaki

props.synopsis: South Korea and Japan are emerging as the early favourites in a multi-billion-dollar competition to build Australia's new fleet of light frigates.

title.children: Asian shipyards battle for lucrative Australian naval contract

image.altText: Kemi Badenoch speaks at a podium after winning the leadership contest.

props.synopsis: Kemi Badenoch, the first black woman to lead a major British political party, pledges to bring the right-of-centre Tories "renewal" by pushing for a smaller state and rejecting identity politics.

title.children: Kemi Badenoch replaces Rishi Sunak as leader of UK Conservative Party

image.altText: A teddy bear sits on a chair amid mud covered streets

props.synopsis: More than 200 bodies are recovered in Europe's worst flood-related disaster since 1967.

title.children: Thousands of troops and police to be sent to Valencia after deadly Spanish floods

image.altText: Hard Quiz host Tom Gleeson smirks behind the podium. The Hard Quiz logo is in the top right corner

props.synopsis: It's time for a reality check. Get ready to play ... HARD!

title.children: Like a Sunday quiz with a serving of sass? Right this way …

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous man wearing a suit looks at the camera

props.synopsis: An Aboriginal Northern Territory politician says he believes racism is worsening in Darwin after he was asked to show identification before refuelling a rental car at a service station.

title.children: Aboriginal politician calls out racism after he was asked to show ID at service station

image.altText: Green post next to road with SUV driving past

props.synopsis: Removing wildlife carcasses from the road is a usual morning for Jason Cichocki but he says a new technology has more than halved the number of animals colliding with vehicles.

title.children: Wildlife rescuers say 'virtual fence' saving hundreds of kangaroos on Victoria's Surf Coast

image.altText: boab treeand old buildings sen through a fence

props.synopsis: Can Western Australia's northernmost town be revived? Locals say they know how to bring the tourists back.

title.children: It may be faded and ageing, but residents see a bright future for once-bustling WA town

image.altText: Kriti Gupta standing on a grassy hill with a lookout over mountains

props.synopsis: Some women of colour think Australia's digital dating culture is "chill". But others have experienced racism on the apps and feel unsure about how a new nationwide code will protect them.

title.children: 'The fear is always there': Women of colour share their experiences of dating apps in Australia

image.altText: A flexible solar panel is printed onto a roll of plastic film

props.synopsis: Solar panels that can be printed out like newspapers and rolled up to fit in your pocket are one step closer thanks to a new development by CSIRO.

title.children: CSIRO's new printing facility could put a solar panel in your pocket

image.altText: A tree has been cut, about a metre from the ground, behind him.

props.synopsis: After finding numerous trees with branches sawn off, WA photographer Lynn Webb is increasingly concerned the lure of $8,000 per kilogram seeds is putting the environment at risk.

title.children: Surging demand for native seeds could fuel illegal harvesting, experts warn
